data.title: The present contains nothing more than the past and what is found in the effect was already in the cause.
data.meta_description: In his quote, Henri Bergson reflects upon the interconnectedness of time and causality. He asserts that the present moment is not an entirely new and independent entity, but rather a culmination of the past. Everything that exists in the present, be it events, experiences, or phenomena, is rooted in the actions and conditions that preceded it. Furthermore, Bergson suggests that causation is not a unidirectional relationship, but rather a dynamic interaction where the effect inherently contains elements of its cause. Therefore, the quote emphasizes how the present is shaped and influenced by the unfolding of past events, and how the cause and effect are intricately intertwined in the course of time.

Quotes Interpret

In his quote, Henri Bergson reflects upon the interconnectedness of time and causality. He asserts that the present moment is not an entirely new and independent entity, but rather a culmination of the past. Everything that exists in the present, be it events, experiences, or phenomena, is rooted in the actions and conditions that preceded it. Furthermore, Bergson suggests that causation is not a unidirectional relationship, but rather a dynamic interaction where the effect inherently contains elements of its cause. Therefore, the quote emphasizes how the present is shaped and influenced by the unfolding of past events, and how the cause and effect are intricately intertwined in the course of time.
